column3: GTMFlow equips executives and organizations with the mindset and tools to thrive through curveballs—unexpected challenges that disrupt performance. Our executive cancer coaching is a scalable benefit that supports employees navigating diagnosis or caregiving, helping them balance work, treatment, and communication to stay resilient and productive.
column7:
A cancer diagnosis is profoundly destabilizing—especially for executives responsible for leading teams, driving strategy, and managing critical customer and investor relationships. These leaders are expected to deliver clarity, momentum, and stability—while suddenly navigating medical decisions, emotional strain, and physical disruption. Most employers offer insurance and clinical support, but they lack real-time, experienced, executive-centric coaching to help executives process the diagnosis, communicate with stakeholders, and balance their dual responsibilities to their health and their company.

Without targeted support, executives often withdraw, make reactive decisions, or disappear from the business when their leadership is most needed. This creates ripple effects across teams and priorities, leading to unnecessary leaves, stalled initiatives, and cultural instability. GTMFlow closes this gap by delivering executive-grade coaching that helps leaders develop a plan, communicate confidently, and stay engaged—so they can protect their health and business continuity.

The stress of navigating perceptions, expectations, and potential marginalization at work often outweighs the medical fear in those early days.

This insight helped me realize that communication isn’t just a tactical issue—it’s an emotional lifeline. I pivoted GTMFlow to address not only decision-making and productivity, but also the deep need for guidance around disclosure, relationship dynamics, and workplace identity after a diagnosis. Our coaching now starts by helping clients build a communication plan rooted in clarity, confidence, and compassion—because the moment they share their diagnosis often defines how supported (or isolated) they’ll feel going forward.

column3: Hero is a smartphone-based VO₂ Max Assessment, delivering science-backed health and fitness insights using only a member’s phone camera. No wearables, no lab visits—just validated, real-time metrics of the most attributable factor in all cause mortality, cardiorespiratory fitness, in 2 minutes.
column7:
We have a global health crisis. We are becoming less active and more sedentary, impacting cardiorespiratory fitness. 
Having a low cardiorespiratory fitness is the most attributable factor in all cause mortality, more impactful than being obese, having diabetes or being a smoker. Cardiorespiratory fitness is measured via VO2 Max, which indicates how effectively and efficiently we are utilising oxygen to exist and perform activity. 
We as a society do not measure VO2 Max and do not have an understanding of it. Why?
VO2 Max testing exists primarily in the elite sports performance setting, due to the inconvenient, costly and scarcity of laboratory testing facilities. 
Hero exists to deliver VO2 Max at scale via smartphone camera technology, to democratise access to the metric by removing inconvenience and prohibitive costs. 
Hero believes that an objective measure of cardiorespiratory fitness is critical in educating, supporting and improving health outcomes at a population level. Improving health outcomes via VO2 Max improvements have hugely significant and well researched financial associated benefits, witnessed in healthcare spend and insurance claims. The objectives and benefits to healthcare/insurance industry and the health of our population are aligned in mission. Be preventative, improve health, reduce cost.

column3: Defiant Health is building a new front door for cancer care, guiding patients through diagnosis in days, not months, and supporting their most important decisions with expertise and attention at every step.

Cancer care is beset with delay, error, and excess cost, diminishing patient outcomes and quality-of-life and increasing the burden on payers, employers, and patients who pay for care. We address those problems by engaging patients early - before they are diagnosed - and supporting the critical initial steps in their journey. 

Our entry point for patient engagement addresses the suffering that patients endure trying to get timely and accurate answers when they suspect they may have cancer. Then, for those who do have a positive diagnosis, we help address the challenge they face in finding the best oncology team for their specific condition and ensure their treatment plan reflects best practice among complex and rapidly evolving treatment options. In total, these interventions not only address patient experience and outcomes, but result in significant cost savings to payers and employers.

During our initial phase of growth, we’ll be targeting regionally-based employers and regional health plans, both commercial and Medicare, with membership that is concentrated geographically. Our core value prop to employers and payers is around cost savings. According to the Business Group on Heath, 86% of employers report that oncology is among their top 3 cost drivers, the highest of any condition. Costs are spiraling, projected at 9% CAGR through 2030. Early incidence of cancer among working-age individuals has grown 31% over the past decade.

Although the core motion is B2B2C, member engagement is critical and thus we have a strong consumer focus as well. Individuals face long waits for diagnostic services and the frustration inherent in navigating a fragmented healthcare environment, all while dealing with the anxiety brought on by the suspicion of cancer. Our ideal profile in this area rides trends in consumer behavior that show individuals more engaged in their own (or loved ones’) healthcare decision making, especially for serious concerns such as cancer. These folks have high expectations for a service experience that is set by other industries (e.g. hospitality, travel, retail), which legacy healthcare often fails to meet. When dissatisfied, they are proactive in seeking consumer-friendly alternatives, primarily through online research, and are even willing to pay out-of-pocket (e.g., second opinion, full-body MRI, at-home testing).

column15:
When it comes to diagnostic services specifically, we’re competing primarily against legacy health systems and providers. There has been relatively little innovation in care delivery for this phase of the patient journey, and it remains fragmented and lacking patient focus. 

More broadly, we “compete” with four types of digital health companies in cancer care: screening & early detection; care navigation; centers of excellence; and second opinion. All suffer from low rates of patient engagement. What they get wrong, we believe, is the time in the patient journey at which they engage. Screening & early detection companies have shortcomings similar to many preventive health solutions in that many individuals,  in the absence of an acute problem, aren’t paying attention. Other solutions, which often rely on claims triggers or other health plan data, engage too late. Once a patient is diagnosed, they typically are rushed to establish care with an oncology team and get a treatment plan in place. Care navigation, COE, and second opinion programs usually don’t get to patients until they have a diagnosis and, at which point, they’ve often made critical decisions regarding their provider or their treatment that are difficult to revisit. 

While these other solutions are competitors in some sense, we believe there is opportunity to partner with them. For example, having engaged a patient during the diagnostic phase, we can then help them evaluate options in a COE program their employer offers.
column16:
Our initial model includes two sources of revenue, connected to two stages of the patient journey:

Stage 1: For patients with a suspicion of cancer, we charge a $400 concierge fee for a same- or next-day consultation with our oncology-trained primary care physicians, immediate access to diagnostic services, assistance in logistics (such as records collection). The concierge fee may be cash pay for individual consumers or part of the covered benefit with plans and employers.

Stage 2: For patients with a confirmed diagnosis, we charge payers a value-based case rate – currently estimated at $8,000 – for a) expedited staging and further diagnostics based on Dana-Farber proprietary diagnostic pathways; b) guidance in selecting a high-value oncologist; c) a “first opinion” treatment recommendation based on Dana-Farber treatment pathways, and d) ongoing support/advocacy from our clinical team.

This case rate is based on projected average per patient savings of >$24,000 from 1) appropriate utilization of diagnostic services, avoiding unnecessary/excessive testing post-biopsy; 2) avoiding higher cost HOPD sites through Defiant's network of independent diagnostic providers; 3) avoiding less effective or excessive treatment through adherence to Dana-Farber treatment pathways; and 4) when appropriate, avoiding higher cost NCI, AMC, or hospital settings for treatment by guiding patients to high-quality community practices.

Faster Access to Neurological Care:
Nearly 50% of employees suffer from at least one neurological condition, yet the average wait time to see a neurologist in the U.S. is over six months. JOGO Health offers virtual neurology consults within 24 hours across all 50 states — improving employee access, reducing absenteeism, and preventing costly disease progression.

Cost-Effective Alternative to High-Cost Treatments:
EMG Biofeedback is recognized as a medical necessity to reduce reliance on Botox, CGRP-inhibitors, and neuromodulation surgeries for migraines and neurological disorders. However, it’s traditionally available only at large academic medical centers. JOGO provides the only FDA-cleared virtual EMG Biofeedback system deliverable via telemedicine — making it easily accessible to your employees wherever they are.

Impact:
Employees who receive JOGO’s virtual neurology consults combined with EMG Biofeedback significantly reduce their use of high-cost medications and invasive procedures — helping employers lower healthcare spend while improving employee well-being and retention.

Our greatest barriers to success are:

Payer and Employer Sales Cycles
Selling into payers, PEOs, and benefits platforms involves long, relationship-driven sales cycles with multiple stakeholders. We mitigate this through strategic pilots, warm intros, and by proving immediate ROI via utilization and cost-savings metrics.

Integration Complexity
Integrating with provider directories, benefit structures, and claims data can be technically complex and vary by customer. We've built modular, API-first infrastructure and leverage existing standards (like MRFs and FHIR) to accelerate deployments.

Trust and Compliance
Handling PHI and influencing care decisions requires deep trust. We're HIPAA-compliant, deploy AI with direct observability in real-time, and ensure human review. Trust is also built through enterprise design: zero training, no downloads, and seamless EDI or portal-based workflows.

Competitive Noise
The digital health space is crowded. But most tools focus narrowly (just scheduling, or just benefits), or fail to personalize at the plan and provider level. Sunny wins by offering an all-in-one AI concierge that knows your network, your plan, and your preferences, and delivers measurable outcomes.

column3: Volta bridges health tech, insurtech, and edtech, leveraging AI and data intelligence to automate regulated insurance and healthcare processes for colleges and universities.
column7:
- Our flagship service addresses a critical compliance requirement for universities. Educational institutions mandate health insurance coverage for their student populations—sometimes due to state regulations (e.g., Massachusetts) and invariably as a risk mitigation, reputation protecting measure. Consider a student who fractures their leg during an intramural game—no matter how comprehensive a university’s health center is, that student will likely need hospital care. If the student lacks adequate insurance, the situation becomes a major headache for the student and university, leading to potential reputational damage, legal liability from parents, retention risks due to medical debt, and even financial liability for hospitals covering uninsured students.Since the Affordable Care Act (ACA), the majority of students—up to 90% in some cases—are covered under their parents’ insurance. Thus, these students can waive out of the university-sponsored health insurance plan (SHIP), but the waiver process is complex. Schools impose specific requirements such as deductible limits, HMO vs. PPO preferences, and restrictions on out-of-state plans, making verification of an entire student body a logistical nightmare.
    - *Universities*
        - Educational institutions face two options for insurance verification: building an in-house verification team or outsourcing to brokerage firms. While some institutions with substantial resources handle this internally (e.g., Yale, Emory), most—even including prestigious institutions like Stanford and Brown—outsource this function at significant expense. Volta reduces these costs by millions of dollars annually. (See below for calculus).
    - *Brokers*
        - Brokerage firms provide two primary services to universities: procurement of official SHIP plan (generating a 5% commission on premium value) and administration of enrollment/waiver processes of said plan (increasing commissions to 15%). Using two New York institutions as examples, NYU's $80 million yearly premium and Columbia's $125 million yearly premium generate $8 million and $12.5 million respectively in commissions for waiver and enrollment administration alone. By partnering with Volta, brokers maintain their commission structure while outsourcing the labor-intensive verification process to us at a fraction of the cost, substantially increasing their profit margins.
    - Payers
        - Insurance providers face considerable challenges in the current ecosystem. Brokers' annual renegotiation practices create unpredictable revenue streams and prevent insurers from recouping implementation costs. Volta enables insurers to bypass brokerage intermediaries by directly addressing universities' most significant pain point—the waiver and enrollment process. While plan selection is relatively straightforward for institutions, it is the managing of verification for thousands of students and dependents presents considerable operational challenges that our platform efficiently resolves.
- Insurance Billing
    - University health centers function as de facto clinics, offering essential medical services to students. Yet, unlike traditional healthcare providers, they *do not bill third party insurance*. Instead, universities absorb these healthcare costs as operational expenses. Volta changes this dynamic. SmartHeritance is a digital legacy planning platform that helps individuals organize and securely pass on everything their loved ones will need - from financial, digital and personal assets to ongoing expenses. 

The reality is, most families face stress, confusion and financial loss when a loved one passes - simply because vital information is scattered, or missing. SmartHeritance solves this by automating the discovery, organization, and secure sharing of key information - ensuring nothing gets lost or unclaimed.

Your legacy is fully preserved and passed on with ease, giving you peace of mind and providing a clear path for your family when it matters most.
column7:
Most families are caught off guard when a loved one passes away. Critical information—like financial accounts, insurance policies, and digital assets—is often scattered or hidden, leaving survivors overwhelmed and unprepared. 

This leads to lost assets, missed benefits, and emotional strain during an already difficult time. SmartHeritance helps individuals organize and securely share key information, so their families aren’t left in the dark when it matters most.

A common pitfall in legacy planning is the lack of ongoing discipline—people may start organizing their affairs but rarely keep things updated. Survivors often don’t know what exists, or who to contact when someone passes away. As a result, assets go unclaimed and critical benefits are missed. SmartHeritance addresses this with automated asset discovery and periodic wellness checks, ensuring that vital information stays current and reaches the right people automatically when it matters most.

Early on, I realized through user interviews that legacy planning is like dental floss—everyone knows they should do it, but almost no one actually does. The barrier wasn’t about importance; it was about discipline, emotional resistance, and the sheer effort involved.

People weren’t just avoiding legal documents—they were overwhelmed by the time it takes to track expenses, organize assets, and keep everything current. Many also pointed out that day-to-day financial details and expenses are a vital part of a family legacy, yet they’re often ignored.

That feedback changed everything. I saw clearly that automation wasn’t a nice-to-have—it was the only way to overcome apathy and make this stick. We pivoted SmartHeritance to focus on a simple, intuitive UI layered with automated asset discovery and wellness checks, turning legacy planning into an easy, ongoing habit. Our goal became clear: reduce the emotional and logistical burden, so families are never left scrambling in the dark.

They shared their own pain: while hiring, they were frustrated by the high costs of job ads and recruiting fees. Why does posting a job or making a hire cost thousands? There had to be a better way. Merging our shared frustration into a simpler, more urgent opportunity: a monetized, community-powered referral system that flips recruiting economics on its head.

Cost predictability: Traditional recruiting channels are expensive and unpredictable. With chainstaff, companies set the bounty upfront and only pay on successful hires, giving full control over hiring spend.

Scaling referrals: Many companies already use internal referral programs but want to expand reach beyond employees. We enable them to tap into external networks without additional complexity.

Manual processes: Some companies still manage referrals in Excel, with manual tracking and payments. chainstaff fully automates the process making it seamless, transparent, and scalable.

column15:
Our competitors include:

Traditional recruiting agencies (e.g. Hays, Adecco): These are expensive (15–30% of first-year salary), slow, and not performance-aligned. They also offer limited transparency and scalability.

Job platforms (e.g. LinkedIn, Indeed): While they offer reach, they don’t activate networks or offer incentives for successful referrals. It’s pay-to-post, not pay-for-performance.

Internal referral tools (e.g. Firstbird, Radancy): These focus only on employees, closed systems that don’t scale beyond the company. They often require upfront SaaS fees and don’t solve the real distribution challenge.

What they get wrong:
They treat referrals as an add-on - we treat them as the core channel. Most fail to unlock the full power of external networks or to build fair, automated reward mechanisms. chainstaff is designed to be radically simple, risk-free (pay only on success), and infinitely scalable, turning every person into a recruiter without friction.
column16:
chainstaff currently operates on a performance-based, success-fee model. Companies post jobs with a self-defined bounty (e.g. 1,000–5,000). When a candidate is hired through a referral, chainstaff charges a 30% platform fee on the total bounty - paid only upon a successful hire. There are no upfront costs, no subscriptions, and zero risk for employers.

This model aligns incentives perfectly: companies only pay when they see value, and referrers are rewarded for results. It’s simple, transparent, and scales naturally with hiring volume.

In parallel, we are actively exploring a licensing model for larger organizations that already have established referral programs but lack automation and external reach. This model would offer companies their own branded version of chainstaff, complete with internal controls, analytics, and full automation. We're conducting market validation and prototyping through Q3 2025, with the goal of launching enterprise pilots by October.

This dual approach allows us to stay lean and scalable with SMEs while unlocking long-term ARR potential with enterprise clients.

Our early pilots confirm the gap: In our first phase, 40+ companies joined without upfront costs, and 5 paid out successful referral bounties. Many of them expressed the same pain: high recruiting costs, low reach, and no structured referral tools beyond internal programs.

Achieving network effect at scale: Our model becomes more powerful as more companies and referrers join. So reaching critical mass fast is essential. Early traction has been good, but scaling sustainably while maintaining quality is a key challenge.

Shifting buyer mindsets: Many companies are used to traditional recruiting channels and may hesitate to adopt performance-based referral systems.

Balancing two-sided onboarding: As a platform, we need to onboard both companies and referrers. While we’ve streamlined the experience, ensuring steady growth and engagement on both sides remains a delicate balance.

That’s exactly why we’re excited about the SemperVirens Accelerator: your team and network are uniquely positioned to help us break through these barriers, especially distribution and enterprise adoption.
column27: While we’re strong in product, strategy, and early-stage sales, our biggest gap is in marketing and scalable customer acquisition. We’ve relied heavily on founder-led outreach and our advisory network, which has worked well for early traction, but we now need to build a repeatable, data-driven growth engine.
column28:
One of the most important pieces of feedback we received early on was that our original vision - building a blockchain-based CV verification and skill-matching infrastructure - was too ambitious and too abstract for immediate market adoption. While technically exciting, it lacked a clear entry point and monetization path.

We listened. Instead of forcing a big, complex idea, we zoomed in on a very real and painful problem every company faces.

That learning led us to pivot - from a future-facing tech stack to a practical, ROI-driven platform. We kept the spirit of our original vision (empowering individuals to own and monetize their data), but grounded it in a tangible, urgent solution companies could adopt today. That shift gave us traction, revenue, and momentum.
